awd_titl_txt: Seismic Velocity Structure of the Aleutian Arc and Bering   Shelf and the Composition of Continental Growth
awd_abstract_narration: 9204998  Klemperer    This research will measure the seismic velocity structure of the  Aleutian Arc and the Bering Sea Shelf in order to provide  constraints on continental growth and composition.  It is widely  believed that two-thirds of the continental crust forming today  does so at magmatic arcs, but, paradoxically, recent geological and  petrological estimates of island arc composition suggest that arcs  are substantially more mafic than average continental crust is  believed to be.  The best test of the composition of in-situ crust  is its seismic velocity, but though many measurements of  continental velocity have been made worldwide, very few data exist  for island arcs because of the logistic difficulties of working in  these areas.  This project is coordinated with two other NSF-funded  projects to collect seismic reflection data via the R/V Ewing under  a University of Delaware and Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory grant  and an ocean-bottom seismometer deployment under a Woods-Hole  Oceanographic Institution grant.  ***
